DEAR DIARY:

About 10 minutes after ''The Croupier'' began rolling at the Screening Room, a small movie theater in Montclair, two couples walked down the aisle, talking loudly. After a public discussion about where to sit, they continued jabbering before settling down.
After making their way to the lobby when the movie ended, the latecomers, without introduction, asked another viewer, ''How did it start?''
The man answered tartly: ''I can't tell you. Some people walked in and talked so loudly, I couldn't hear the movie.''
Carl Sommers
Scene: Ridgewood street fair.

A couple -- the man an impulse buyer, the woman a skeptic -- stop at a booth where cell phone accessories are sold. After paying $49 for a device to recharge a phone in a car, his partner says, ''I think you'd better try that out right away.''
They dash to their car and -- sure enough -- the gadget doesn't work.
''Let's hurry back to return this gizmo,'' she says. ''I bet the vendor will say, 'Your phone's too old.' ''
Approaching the booth, the woman reads the vendor's lips as he says to an assistant, ''Here comes a credit.''
The man reports, ''This gadget doesn't fit my phone.''
To which the vendor replies, ''Your phone's too old,'' and quickly turns to a new prospect.
The new customer, a youth, needs an earphone, which the vendor proceeds to pitch. The youth then takes the latest model cell phone from his pocket and plugs in the attachment. It doesn't work.
This time the vendor says, ''Your phone's too new.''

The couple and the young man meet at another stand and find they have something in common: zeppoli. The man pays off his bet to the skeptical woman and treats the surprised youth. They slowly walk away from the great street fair.
Florenz Greenberg
Bumper sticker seen at a Rutgers football game: ''Drive Safe. Pick Up Girls, Not Phones.''
Audrey Corn
TAN LITTLE INDIANS
I think I'll never understand
The ladies, chic and summer-tanned
Who, complimented thereon in belated
September tributes, won't concur.
Instead they'll shrug, protest, demur,
Insisting loudly, ''But my tan's all faded.''
Maureen Cannon

I was visiting a childhood friend, Mike, his wife, Barbara, and their two daughters on a late-summer evening in Spring Lake. The girls had been rambunctious for much of the day, and Mike had confided that he was feeling a bit haggard and irritated.
As we all stood in line for an Italian ice, a pregnant and radiant young woman strolled by. Enchanted by the girls' apple-cheeked faces, she stopped and cooed at them.
''You just wait until you have yours,'' Mike muttered as he watched her walk away. ''You'll get your tubes tied up like the Gowanus Expressway.''
Brian Blatz
ALL SOCKS DON'T COME IN PAIRS
I collect lots of unmatched socks,
While others collect exotic rocks.
I can't use them in summer and spring,
But fall and winter are my thing.
Out come my boots all shiny and new,
On go my socks, one pink, one blue.
Shirley Walker
